title: 107_hr4018
content: The Act titled "Veterans Judicial Review Improvement Act of 2002" establishes a standard for the reversal of erroneous findings of fact. The "Veterans Judicial Review Improvement Act of 2002" changes the standard for reversing erroneous findings of fact in title 38, United States Code. The amendments specify that a decision adverse to a claimant must be supported by a preponderance of evidence. The Court will review the record of proceedings before the Secretary and the Board when making determinations. These changes apply to actions under chapter 72 of title 38 that are not final as of the enactment date of the Act. The jurisdiction of the Court of Appeals for Veterans Claims is expanded to allow for default judgments against the Secretary in cases of unlawful withholding or unreasonable delays. The Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit has jurisdiction to review decisions made by the Court of Appeals for Veterans Claims. Expansion of Jurisdiction: Section 7292 of title 38, United States Code, is amended to include review of questions of law relied on by the Court in making decisions. Effective Date: The amendments apply to cases with appeals filed on or after a specified date with the United States Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit. The United States Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit will have jurisdiction over cases with appeals filed on or after a specified date, including those not final under section 7291 of title 38, United States Code. SEC. 5. CODIFICATION OF REQUIREMENT FOR EXPEDITIOUS TREATMENT OF CASES ON REMAND. Amends Chapter 51 of title 38, United States Code to include a new section requiring expedited treatment of remanded claims by the Veterans Benefits Administration regional office. SEC. 6. Expedited treatment of remanded claims by the Court of Appeals for Veterans Claims, with the Secretary required to take necessary actions for prompt processing. Repeal of Section 302 of the Veterans' Benefits Improvement Act of 1994. Allows the Court of Appeals for Veterans Claims to order interim benefits on remanded claims. The Court of Appeals for Veterans Claims can order the Secretary to pay interim benefits if a remanded claim is not decided within 180 days. Payments start after the 180-day period and end when the final decision is made. The Court of Appeals for Veterans Claims can order interim benefits to be paid if a claim is not resolved within 180 days. The order for interim benefits is final and not subject to review. If benefits are awarded in the final decision, interim benefits are deducted from retroactive payments. If no benefits are awarded, interim benefits are not considered overpayment and not recoverable by the United States. The amendment made by subsection (a) applies to actions under chapter 72 of title 38, United States Code, that are not final as of the enactment date of this Act. SEC. 7. Authority for court to extend time to file notice of appeal under title 38, United States Code, upon showing of excusable neglect or good cause. Effective Date: The amendment does not apply if the time for filing a notice of appeal has already passed before the enactment of this Act.
